Award.AwardTitle: Symposium on Indigenous Rights and Workshop on Collaboration and Comparative Research in the North Pacific
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award to supports the travel expenses for 11 US based Arctic scholars to participate in a 3 day symposium/workshop that will take place from January 11-13th, 2014 at the National Museum of Ethnology, Senri Expo Park, Osaka, Japan. The main goals of the workshop are 1) to present current research on the status of indigenous rights in the North Pacific Region; 2) to facilitate discussions on collaborations and comparative research in the region; 3) to open a discussion on the creation of a North Pacific social science association that could facilitate scientific exchanges and scholarship in the region. The meeting strategy is to invite a set of scholars who cover a range of geographic, cultural and theoretical research areas and who have strong research experience working with indigenous communities; 4 of the scholars are indigenous people themselves.

This workshop is a unique opportunity for building collaborations between the US and the Japanese social science community that will support research on the Pacific Rim. The Pacific Rim region is of great interest to arctic social science because of its long history of east/west connections (dating back over 14,000 years) combined with its rapidly changing social and cultural systems affected by pressures from globalizing economies to climate change. Rarely have US and Japanese social scientists collaborated on scholarship in what is a region of great mutual interest to each; this workshop will provide that opportunity.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary outcome of the project was an international, interdsciplinary symposium concerning indigenous rights and North Pacific research collaboration and coordination. The symposium was hosted and in part supported by the National Museum of Ethnology in Osaka, Japan. It took place January 11th to 13th, 2014, during which time 21 authors and co-authors presented 17 papers. The program was divided in three subject areas for each of the three days: (1) “Indigenous rights and the utilization of marine resources in the North Pacific Rim”; (2) “Comparative study of indigenous cultures along the North Pacific Rim”; and (3) “Joint research on indigenous cultures of the North Pacific.” The papers included presentations of: the social and cultural dimensions of marine resource subsistence and management; comparative studies on each side of and across the Pacific and developments in the archaeology of the region. The geographical scope of the presentations included Alaska, British Columbia, the Russian Far East and Japan. The level and extent of scientific exchange was greatly enhanced by simultaneous interpretation in Japanese and English provided by the museum. Thanks to the translation and fully equipped conference hall, all the speakers and the audience were able to participate in questions and discussions. The grant helped to support diversity among the presenters. Not including the PI, the grant supported two indigenous researchers and three non-indigenous and of those five, one was senior, four were mid-career.  Four of the invited researchers were US citizens, two were Russian and one Canadian.  Unfortunately, two of the Russian indigenous invitees, both women and one a junior researcher, were unable to attend because of travel difficulties from their rural places of residence.

In addition to the presentations, participants discussed the possibility of establishing a North Pacific social science research association as a network for potential future collaborations and intellectual exchange. One outcome of those discussions was the creation of a North Pacific social science listserv hosted at Oxford University. Discussions also emreged concerning the possible foundation of a journal as one of the functions of the North Pacific Social Science Research Association.  The National Museum of Ethnology offered to publish papers from the symposium in a special edition of its ethnological series and several papers have been submitted. Inspired by the success of the symposium three additional North Pacific meetings convened during the subsequent two years.  In direct response to the Osaka symposium, Virginie Vaté, Claire Alix and David Koester organized a one-day workshop on North Pacific research in Paris, France. It was held on November 4, 2014, under the auspices of the Research Group “Mutations Polaires” and the “Groupe sociétés, réligions et laïcités” of the French National Research Center (CNRS). This NSF grant supported participation in the workshop by Tatiana Khelol, an indigenous Koryak social science researcher from northern Kamchatka. As the only French speaking indigenous scholar from the region, she offered frank and critical commentary on the presentations. The all-day workshop consisted of six presentations with a total of nine authors and co-authors.
